text: All right. Thank you very much. Thank you very much, Mr. Page. I will go ahead and just jump right into it. Good evening, school board members, colleagues,  and school community members. Before I get started, I would like to share my gratitude with our school community, our students, families, employees, and partners for all that you have done to support Albemarle County Public Schools and for your efforts to keep Albemarle County Public Schools moving forward during the pandemic. We have learned that everyone's support is needed to truly fulfill the mission of our schools.  That mission is the title of our strategic plan and our draft funding request. It is learning for all. It is the idea that our schools are here for all children and families through the trust and resources of the whole community. This year, as part of our strategic plan to empower communities, we ask our principals and department heads  to host focus groups made up of students and employees to hear their ideas to improve working, learning, and climate conditions in their departments and schools. We used the Virginia Department of Education's School Climate and Working Conditions Survey results for each school as the basis for these conversations. We have channeled the themes and ideas from that engagement through the strategic plan during the planning part of our cycle.  And now we are moving into the budget development phase with our school board. After this phase, we will move toward adoption. As we take time to review our budget goals, our budget development goals, goals that our school board established approximately four years ago, I'm going to pause to say thank you specifically to our fiscal services department. Amy Hottinger, Anita Moore,  Anne Heinemann, Avis Morse, Christopher Harper, Dan Chipman, Jackson Zimmerman, Liz Perkins, Mayakumazawa, Michelle Shifflett, Nanette DeFrank, Rita Dean, and Stephanie Grady. Thank you. These budgeting goals really serve as a quality check for me to be transparent  If I knew nothing else about ACPS, my takeaway from these guidelines is that our school board plans ahead, puts people first, especially children, makes sure that our taxpayers' dollars are spent according to the plan, and insists that we follow the plans we say we have for each dollar allocated. I've mentioned our strategic plan a few times already, and here is the outline of the plan on just one slide.  including the overarching vision, mission, values, and the big strategic goals of our plan, Learning for All. Our plan is locally created, locally situated, and through our collaboration with Battelle for Kids, it is a nationally benchmarked plan. While we developed the plan in consultation with diverse representation from our students, employees, families, and community members,  The plan shows alignment with national level research and best practices. The fiscal year 2023 draft funding requests asks for investments in all three of our big strategic goals, thriving students, affirming and empowering communities, and equitable transformative resources. The strategic plan is a compass for our funding requests.  and it acts as a guide, giving direction for our resources and actions. We also have a context for our funding requests that truly sets the stage for our work, not just for next year, but for years to come. Maybe it goes without saying, but as we watch the headlines scroll on this slide, I will say that every issue we are facing here in Albemarle County Public Schools  is an issue for public school systems all over Virginia and across the country. Every problem, every challenge, every opportunity you name that is impacting us here in ACPS is a national problem. Our draft spending plan aims to keep us on the course we set through our strategic plan and aims to help us do what we can to bolster the stability of our workforce.  our employees as we move forward. Yes, students, families, educators, staff, administrators, and so many others in school districts, state educational agencies, institutions of higher education, and communities across the country are immersed in the hard work of ensuring equal educational opportunity for all students. One benefit or silver lining  to facing challenges that are widespread is the opportunity to learn ideas from others that will help us succeed. Whether through meeting weekly with superintendents from Region 5, attending the National Ed Leader 21 Superintendents Roundtable each month, submitting research requests and attending webinars provided by our national research partner, the Education Advisory Board,  or through attending Virginia Association of School Superintendents gatherings, my staff and I have tried to learn from the successes and mistakes of others, as well as our own, as we have been navigating the pandemic. Many of our lessons learned are reflected in our draft funding request for FY23. And so, as we get into more specific details of the funding request through our next several slides, I'll bring back the strategic plan  one more time into focus. All of the strategies to which we asked the board to consider allocating resources are aligned to the three big goals of the strategic plan. Over the following series of slides, I will provide just some highlights of our strategies for accomplishing the big strategic goals through our budget. I will begin with goal one, thriving students.  In just a couple of weeks, we will be in the month of March, which is the Virginia School Boards Association's Equity in Education Month. Here's what the VSBA has to say about equity in education. When inequity in education persists, there is a cost to all involved, including missed opportunities for economic development, greater dependence on government supports, and fewer Virginians ready to serve and lead.  With the added inequities that have resulted from the COVID-19 pandemic and the challenges that we are faced with economically, it is more important now than ever before that we, advocates and servants of public education, are addressing these inequities head on. This is why it is so important that all of our students thrive academically, socially, and emotionally in our schools. Not some or most, but all. All means all.  And I want to remind our community that in our current school year, the school board has made substantial investments in research-based strategies, the tried and true methods to address our students' academic recovery. Our board doubled the amount of intervention funding for each school in order to increase intervention time and expand tutoring opportunities with an investment from the federal recovery funding.  Last summer we sued a half million dollars in recovery funding to expand summer programming. We invested $2.5 million in recovery funding to reduce class sizes this year below pre pandemic levels through additional staffing. And our board invested $2.3 million in recovery funding to add a counseling position to each school dedicated to coordinating mental health support and family engagement.  All of these investments are in progress in the current school year and intended to positively impact students' academic recovery. I am certain that all of us would agree that the most important element for a thriving student is a qualified and collaborative educator. In Albemarle County, our school community values small class sizes. And over time, through the focused investment of our school board,  and through both regular and differentiated staffing, we have reduced our student to teacher ratios in our elementary and secondary schools far below those required by the Virginia Department of Education. Note that in FY 2020, our average elementary class size of 19.6 is approximately four or five students below what the state requires through the standards of quality. On these charts,  the state's class size standards are marked with a star. Ours are marked with a circle. Also in FY 2020, our average class sizes of 21.5 for middle schools and 21.6 for high schools were approximately three students smaller than those required by the standards of quality. During the 21-22 school year, class sizes were reduced further  due to lower than projected enrollments and by allocating additional FTEs using federal one-time pandemic relief funds. This proposal adds 30.5 FTEs in recurring operating expenses with a goal to maintain the average class sizes seen during the 21-22 school year.  Our draft funding request proposal reduces our current average staffing ratio by one student at each school level. Our ACPS mission statement says that working together as a team, we will end the predictive value of race, class, gender, and special capacities for our children's success through high quality teaching and learning for all. We seek to build relationships with families and communities  to ensure that every student succeeds. We will know every student. With that mission as our guide, we must adapt to the changing needs of our students and families if we are to be successful in meeting the learning needs of all students. Because when we are successful in reducing the impact of achievement gaps for our historically marginalized students, we will be more successful with all of our students.  Though we've seen fairly static enrollment of students with disabilities over the course of the pandemic, the needs of the students we serve continue to increase in severity. In response, our fiscal year 23 funding request includes an additional 8.98 FTEs to bolster our specialty staffing models. These models include specially trained teams of special educators and instructional assistants  We use evidence-based practices to address the specific and complex needs of groups of students, as well as individual students. This shift recognizes that different students need different levels of support within the context of maximizing access of students with disabilities to the general education classroom and their typically developing peers. This evening's work session  will feature more details and discussion around our special education staffing models. When we look at staffing for our English as a second or other language program, or ESOL, we see a similar staffing strategy, one based on the belief that students with different needs require different levels of supports. Since our September 30th count, only four and one half months ago,  An additional 106 English learners have joined our school division. Based on Virginia staffing standards, which mandate that we must staff 20 ESOL teachers for every 1,000 English learners, we should be funding about 30 FTEs. But we currently fund 37, and we're asking for one more FTE in this funding request.  Our request supports a differentiated staffing model that allows us the flexibility and responsiveness we need to support the individual needs of our English learners. Learners who present varying levels of English proficiency, learners who are spread out across all of our 25 schools and 726 square mile county, learners who have experienced interruptions in their formal education, and some learners who present complex trauma profiles.  increasing the need for additional staff to support both language acquisition and social emotional learning. ESOL staffing is another area we will discuss in more detail during tonight's work session. Another form of staffing that has really turned out to be increasingly critical and one that we want to leave less up to chance so that we can support our educators and our students is our substitute teacher workforce.  In an effort to attract more highly qualified substitute teachers, ACPS will implement multiple substitute program improvements. We aim to help schools provide in-person instruction when faced with teacher absences by staffing each school with one to four permanent substitute teachers, depending on the size of the school. We aim to improve same-day fill rates by increasing the daily compensation we offer substitute teachers.

text: And we will do these things, while maintaining competitiveness in the current wage market to attract high quality substitute teachers. This proposal adds 46 school based substitutes and one central substitute coordinator.  Our need to affirm and empower communities within the schools is crucial for our students' success. In fact, one of our four core values is as articulated in our strategic plan is family and community. We will engage with and share the responsibility for success for students, families, and community partners. Over the next four slides, I will share  four strategies we propose to fund in fiscal year 23 to create greater affirmation and empowerment within our community. Expansion of resources for culturally responsive teaching, professional development, sustaining our increased school counselor presence for the coming school year, devoting time and resources to our community forum initiatives, and funding our technology replacement program.  We propose an increase of just under $200,000 to add more stipend opportunities for culturally responsive teaching. All new ACPS educators are required to participate in Alamo County Public Schools culturally responsive teaching training. The funding request also includes $100,000 in additional funds for professional learning stipends for classified employees  so that our classified staff may be reimbursed for professional development expenditures, just like our licensed employees. In fiscal year 20, we elevated the safety and well-being of our students at our five smaller elementary schools by increasing the part-time school counselor allocation at each school to a full-time position.  The proposal added 2.5 FTEs. Also in fiscal year 20, we expanded our counseling program at the middle school level by adding one FTE between Jack Jewett and Lakeside Middle Schools. In fiscal year 22, even in the midst of decreasing enrollment, we added one full-time counselor to support social emotional learning at every school using one-time federal funds, adding a total of 24 FTEs.  We're proposing to maintain this level of service in fiscal year 23. Plus we're adding one FTE for a counselor at center one in response to increasing enrollment there. Last fall, the division began hosting student, family and employee forums in alignment with goal two of our strategic plan. With the intention of sharing ways to connect and to get the most out of engaging with ACPS.  By holding a series of brief, focused, engaging forums with small and diverse groups of these stakeholders, we hope to affirm and empower participants, increase their connectivity with us, and create a ripple effect of engagement among their circles of influence. Also at the division level, the International and ESOL program, in partnership with our Department of Technology, hosts a monthly technology support night for multilingual families.  These meetings, each of which features different technology topics, provide an excellent opportunity for multilingual families to get the answers to their technology questions that they need and to connect with each other. At the school level, this fall, every principal was asked to host two meetings in October, one for students and one for staff, to solicit input on how we might improve  school climate and working conditions through budget proposals for the 2022-23 school year. Then at the end of October, we asked two students and two employees from every school to come together in a division-wide meeting to discuss budget priorities for the fiscal year of 23. Additionally, the division hosted a number of information sessions and other community engagement opportunities this year.  There's a long list of topics here. I'm not going to read them all from my notes, but many were relevant to ACPS, including COVID-19 mitigation strategies, what is culturally responsive teaching, anti-racism orientation, equitable grading practices, school safety, high school redesign,

Our technology replacement proposal prioritizes providing exceptional support of our digital learning environment, optimal functioning of complex machines and programs, and digital security. Our ability to support these priorities hinges on reliable hardware capable of running up-to-date resources, as well as an adequate number of talented staff members who can provide individualized and timely support to our teachers, students, and staff.  Again, there's a long list of technology replacement items that I have here in my notes. They include machines such as student laptop replacements, teacher laptop replacements, display technology. text: We will provide every student with the level of support necessary to thrive. What is the best way to embody this value in ACPS? It is to ensure that our educators and support staff have what they need to address the academic, emotional, and physical needs of their students. The slides in this final section will highlight just a few of the resources  employee-related, and capital we have identified to meet the needs of our students, employees, and families. Our staff retention and recruitment proposal includes strategies for attracting, developing, and retaining the highest quality staff while leveraging our resources to meet the compensation needs of our staff.  During the current year, we are implementing a 4% compensation increase in a little over a week from now. In addition, a 6% salary increase is proposed for the beginning of FY 22-23 on July 1st. In addition to these steps, a comprehensive compensation study is planned in the coming spring to review instructional and classified positions against their true competitive markets.  and to provide further recommendations for teacher and classified pay scales and the supplemental pay schedule. $880,000 of this proposal will be used for targeted pay increases for certain hard to fill positions based on internal reviews as well as the results of the compensation study. An additional $350,000 of the proposal will be used to provide adjustment pay to select groups of non-exempt employees  due to changes in the payroll structure and cycle that we've been going through. We can explain in more detail during the compensation work session. This strategy is a way to continue to help hourly employees cope with our mandated change to positive pay. Besides helping to bridge gaps in pay periods,  These adjustments will have the added benefit of increasing the overall annual pay for positions such as bus drivers, teaching assistants, and office assistants above the compensation increases we are proposing. And one more note, with the pay increases outlined on this slide, we will have completed the work to guarantee our promise of the $15 minimum wage proposal that the school board approved to begin in fiscal year 22.  $2.4 million of our proposal and our proposed spending plan will go toward covering a rate increase for our health insurance plan without sharing the increased cost with employees. Our current health insurance premiums actually went into effect five years ago in the 2016-17 school year.  With the exception of a temporary increase lasting only six months from October 2017 to March 2018, we have not had a rate increase for employee health insurance since then. Alma County Public Schools and Alma County government are both currently supported by one human resources department. And this has been the case for at least two decades.  We have decided to separate into two human resources departments to better serve our locality's growing and more complex workforce needs. As of July 1st, 2023, our goal is to restructure staff and provide the technological support for our human resources department to shift to what I would refer to as an employee services department. In order for us to accomplish the creation of our own HR department, we will need to add staffing,  and restructure the department with four dedicated focus areas, a center for expertise that focuses on HR functions, such as compensation, benefits, wellness, and safety, a service center to allow employees both self-service and in-person access to respond to their questions, and business partners who will work with ACPS leaders, including principals and department heads, and employees to support school, department, and or employee needs.  And we will need to invest in a human resources information system or an HR is dedicated to our mall county public schools employees. Right now, all major technology operations for human resources are currently owned operated and supported by our mall county local government. As such, a CPS will need to implement its own HR is to support the HR related needs in the school system.  Two FTEs are recommended to be added to the Department of Technology to serve as an HRIS administrator and as a technical support specialist. This proposal adds 3.5 FTEs to the Department of Human Resources, the aforementioned FTEs to the Department of Technology, and will need to add funding for new talent and recruitment expenses, as well as for ongoing costs associated with the Human Resources Information System.  Now this is a new section to our draft funding request. As part of the needs-based funding request for fiscal year 23, I want to bring attention to our capital needs. The highest priority capital projects as recommended by the Long-Range Planning Advisory Committee on September 9, 2021, and affirmed by the school board on October 14, 2021, are listed on this slide.  These are the school division's top capital needs over the next five years. While the operating budget moves us forward with regard to the services provided to our students, employees, and community, without the underlying facilities infrastructure that provides adequate capacity and optimal learning environments, we will be severely hindered in our work. Requested school renovations at all levels would mean substantive investments in our school buildings, including the implementation  of recommendations of the high school master plan study. A phased multi-year approach would bring the school division's aging schools to modern standards to include improvements such as electrical infrastructure updates to accommodate technology, ensuring classrooms have natural light, improvements to adhere to the Americans with Disabilities Act, outdoor learning spaces, and reconfiguration of spaces to improve function, efficiency, and safety.  Perhaps the most substantial roadblock to continuous improvement facing our school communities are teaching and learning spaces that average more than 50 years in age and are limited so that we are forced to utilize more than 80 mobile classrooms or trailers at 12 or about one half of our schools. We have not added a new school to our division in 20 years when the population of our county was 30% less than it is today.  Regional planners advise us that over the next 30 years, Albemarle County's population will expand by another 30%. The strategy of continually expanding facilities built in the early years of the 20th century and continuing to add even more mobile classrooms is not sustainable. It's not in the best interest educationally for our children and their families, nor does it represent our future as a thriving and prosperous county.

Students have experienced learning environments known to no other generation of young people. Learning has been different, not lost. Students have felt the support of caring adults who enthusiastically offer the expertise and their will to keep alive curiosity and energy, to focus on assets and not deficits, to advance learning for all.  I'd like to thank our school board, our board of supervisors, and our partners in local government who come together to support our important work by putting student interests and those of our families and our community first. I must thank the cabinet and the leadership team for your strategic and technical support. Our communication staff has provided excellent support through this process and will continue to do so. I want to especially name Jennifer Butler for creating the slides to tell our story and precise images.  And I want to thank Maya Kumazawa for your technical approach and your strategic vision. Thank you for your time and consideration. Mr. Page.
